S.W.1., on FRIDAY,MARCH 20th, IS25, at 11A.M.PRESENT:-The Right Eon. Stanley Baldwin, M.p.,Prime Minister.e Right Hon.Austen Chamberlain, M.P.,Seoretary of State forForeign Affairs.e Right Hon.W.S. Churchill, CE.,M,P.,Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Right Hon.Sir laming Worthington-Evans,Bart. ,G.B.E. ,M.P. , Secretaryof State for War.e Right Hon.W.C. Sir Douglas Hogg,L. c, ,M .p . , Att orney-General.M.P.A. Hankey, G.C.B.................Secretary. (This Document is the Property of Fis BritannicMajTesty^ .S Government. )"* '- S E C R S I -DLESTON.CABINET 17 (25),CONCLUSIONS of-a.Meeting of the Cabinet,held, in the Prime Minister's Room, Houseof Commons, on FRIDAY, MARCH 20th, 1925,at 11 a*m.ATH OF THE 1. The Cabinet asked the Prime Minister to conveyRQUESSRZON OF to the Marchioness Curzon their deep sympathy and an expression of the irreparable loss which the Cabinet,no less than the country as a whole, had sustained onthe death of the Marquess Curzon. 2. The Cabinet bad before them the following documents relating to the recent interviev/s betweenthe Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs andM* Herriot at Paris, on his way to and from Geneva,as well as to the proceedings at Geneva in connectionwith the Geneva Protocol and Security:-A Letter from Mr Austen Chamberlainto Sir Byre Crowe (Paper CP.-144 (25)):A Letter from Mr Austen Chamberlainto Sir Byre Crowe (Paper CP.-145 (25)):A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs (paper cp.-149 (2555:A Letter from Mr Austen Chamberlain toSir Eyre Crowe (Paper CP.-159 (25)):A Letter from Mr Austen Chamberlain toSir Byre Crowe (Paper CP.-166 (25)):A Memorandum by the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs (Paper CP.-168 (25)).The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs madea statement to the Cabinet of the impressions andopinions he had formed as the result of his visits to Paris and Geneva.After a full discussion, the Cabinet took note of the existing engagements of Great Britain and theDominions, as well as of all signatories to the versailles Treaty, to treat any infringement byGermany of the Treaty provisions for the deMlitarisedzone as a hostile act, arid agreed -(a) That in the forthooining Debate in theHouse of Commons on Tuesday, March 24th,the Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs should be authorised to take ,"thefollowing line.-In regard to the Geneva Protocol, tosay whatever is necessary to supplement ,the statement he had already made atGeneva, which had been published inthis country; to make it clear that X was a mistake to suppdse that the"adoption of the Geneva Protocol wouldhave satis fled the countries on the Continent of Europe on the questionof security, a settlement of whichwas vital to the complete establish-ment of peace; that the recent pro-posals of the German Government appearedto offer the best basis for reaching asettlement on security, but that such asettlement could not possibly be reachedwithout our co-operation; that our responsibilities under these proposals would be limited to entering Into some arrangement providing for mutual guarantee of security of the frontiersbetween Germany, on the one hand, andBelgium and Prance on the other9 towhich Great Britain, Prance, belgium and Germany would be parties;that if we refused to enter into anysuch arrangement and reverted to apolicy of Isolation, the only result would be an aggravation of the exist-Ing unrest on the Continent of Europe,leading ultimately to a fresh war.As bearing on the Eastern and Southernfrontiers of Germany, he should pointout that it was no part of our pro-posals that by entering into specialengagements In respect of the Westernfrontiers we should in any way diminish the guarantees provided elsewhere by existing Treaties. Above all, he shouldmake it clear that, in the view of theGovernment, the peace of the worlddepends on the part which Great britain is prepared to play In this matter.(b) That the Seoretary of State for ForeignAffairs, in consultation with such repre-sentatives of the Colonial Office as he might deem desirable in the absence ofthe, Secretary of State for the Colonies,should draft a telegram for the PrimeMinister to send immediately, throughthe usual channels, to the Prims ministers of the Dominions, notifying tn them theGovernments intention to announce theabove policy on Tuesday, March 24th.(c) That the Prime Minister and the Secretaryof State for Foreign Affairs should seethe High Commissioners of the dominions on Monday, March 23rd, in order to explain the policy more fully.Cd) That appropriate steps should be takent,o' arrange, if possible, that representa-tives of the Dominions at the next Assemblyjbf the League of fetions should arrive inLondon a fortnight before the Meeting of theAssembly, in order fully to discuss thesematters with the British Government.^e) To take note that the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs had made It clear toM. Herriot that the next step was with the latter, and that he had asked him tostate what provisions he considered necessary as regards the Southern (Austrian)and Eastern frontiers of Germany.(f) To congratulate and thank the Secretaryof State for Foreign Affairs for hishandling of the situation at paris and Geneva. NORTHERNIRELANDUNEMPLOYMENTINSURANCEFUND-(previous reference:Cabinet 16(25), Con-elusion 15. )3. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Minister of Labour in regard to the NorthernIreland Unemployment Insurance Fund (Paper CP.-167(25)).The Chancellor of the Exchequer informed theCabinet that he had had an interview the same ,morningwith Lord Londonderry and two other Ministers ofNorthern Ireland. In regard to two of the principaldifficulties in an amalgamation of the UlsterUnemployment Insurance Fund with the British-fundthey had offered - '- v.., (i) That responsibility for the existingdeficit, amounting' to approximately " 2,000,000, should be assumed by theGovernment of Northern Ireland:(ii) That the British Minister of labour should be given an absolutely freehand in regard to the control of theadministration of the' Fund in NorthernIreland.The Cabinet agreed (a) That, on grounds of equity, it was desirable in principle to find some means of assisting Northern ireland in its difficulties in regard to theUnemployment Insurance Fund:(b) That the form of the assistance,"including the kind.of legislation that would be required, should be examined by a Cabinet Committee, tobe composed as follows:-The Lord Chancellor (in the Chair),The Chancellor of the Exchequer,The Secretary of State for War,The Secretary of State for India,The Minister of Labour.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,March 20, 192 5.
